objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to introduce the k-agents framework, designed to automate laboratory experiments by organizing laboratory knowledge and automating experiments with agents, particularly in the context of quantum computing.
objective.evidence: This paper introduces the k-agents framework, designed to support experimentalists in organizing laboratory knowledge and automating experiments with agents.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the challenge of integrating unstructured, multimodal laboratory knowledge into AI systems for effective automation, which is crucial for reducing human effort and improving the efficiency of scientific discovery.
knowledge_gap.evidence: However, effective automation requires deep integration of laboratory knowledge, which is often unstructured, multimodal, and difficult to incorporate into current AI systems.

answer: Introduction of the k-agents framework that uses large language model-based agents to encapsulate laboratory knowledge.
Development of execution agents that break multi-step experimental procedures into agent-based state machines.
Application of the framework to autonomously plan and execute experiments on a superconducting quantum processor.
Use of knowledge-based agents to manage laboratory knowledge without fine-tuning.
evidence: Our framework employs large language model-based agents to encapsulate laboratory knowledge including available laboratory operations and methods for analyzing experiment results.
To automate experiments, we introduce execution agents that break multi-step experimental procedures into agent-based state machines.
To demonstrate its capabilities, we applied the agents to calibrate and operate a superconducting quantum processor.
We developed tools for users to transfer their knowledge, creating LLM-based knowledge agents to manage laboratory knowledge without fine-tuning.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- Boiko et al. (2023) Pioneering efforts to develop automated LLM-based agents to carry out experiments. (Methodological precursors)
- Bran et al. (2024) Limitations in scalability, which constrain their ability to manage complex toolsets and long-horizon tasks. (Papers with limitations addressed by this work)
inspirational_papers.evidence: Despite challenges, pioneering efforts to develop automated LLM-based agents to carry out experiments are already underway [32–35].

steps.step: Decompose experiment procedures into agent-based state machines.
steps.output: Agent-based state machine with experiment stages.
steps.evidence: The execution agent first decomposes it into an agent-based state machine, which contains experiment stages.
Translation agents are responsible for translating an incoming instruction into executable code.
The execution agent will select a reasonable response from the translation agents and execute the translated code.

steps.step: Analyze experiment results and determine next steps.
steps.evidence: Based on the report and the transition rules, determines the next stage to transition to.

tools.name: Large Language Models (LLMs)
tools.description: Used for translating instructions and generating code.
tools.evidence: Our framework employs large language model-based agents to encapsulate laboratory knowledge.

tools.name: Execution Agents
tools.description: Coordinate knowledge agents and manage complex experiment procedures.
tools.evidence: We further introduce the execution agent, which is responsible for coordinating the knowledge agents.

evaluation_metrics.name: Translation Accuracy
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the correctness of translating instructions into executable code.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to benchmark the performance of k-agents in translating instructions.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: Our results show that the GPT-4o model has the best performance and archives an accuracy of 97%.

methods.name: Transformation/structurization of user input
methods.description: The system transforms natural language experiment procedures into structured agent-based state machines.
methods.evidence: The execution agent first decomposes it into an agent-based state machine, which contains experiment stages.

methods.name: Knowledge Extraction and Structurization
methods.description: The system extracts and organizes laboratory knowledge into LLM-based agents.
methods.evidence: Our framework employs large language model-based agents to encapsulate laboratory knowledge.

methods.name: Experimental design generation
methods.description: The approach includes producing experimental protocols, configurations, or evaluation strategies.
methods.evidence: The execution agent transforms the task of executing the procedure into executing the agent-based state machine.

areas.name: Applied Sciences & Engineering
areas.description: The paper develops a framework for automating experiments in quantum computing laboratories.
areas.evidence: We applied the agents to calibrate and operate a superconducting quantum processor.

areas.name: Interdisciplinary Sciences
areas.description: The framework integrates AI and quantum computing for laboratory automation.
areas.evidence: Our knowledge-based agent system opens up new possibilities for managing laboratory knowledge and accelerating scientific discovery.

performance_summary.summary: The k-agents framework successfully automated the calibration and operation of a superconducting quantum processor, achieving performance comparable to human scientists.
performance_summary.evidence: They autonomously planned and executed experiments for hours, successfully producing and characterizing entangled quantum states at the level achieved by human scientists.

baselines.name: Standard RAG methods
baselines.description: Used for comparison in translation accuracy.
baselines.evidence: We compare k-agents (marked as Agents), which uses Algorithm 1, with standard RAG methods.

evaluation_metrics.name: Translation Accuracy
evaluation_metrics.purpose: Measures the correctness of translating instructions into executable code.
evaluation_metrics.application: Used to benchmark the performance of k-agents in translating instructions.
evaluation_metrics.evidence: Our results show that the GPT-4o model has the best performance and archives an accuracy of 97%.

limitations.name: Dependency on Structured Knowledge
limitations.description: The framework relies on clean and well-formatted codebases and procedure documents, which may not always exist.
limitations.evidence: Our method relies on clean and well-formatted codebases and procedure documents.

limitations.name: Higher Latency
limitations.description: The execution of k-agents exhibits higher latency than traditional automation methods.
limitations.evidence: Using LLM, the execution of k-agents exhibits higher latency than traditional automation methods.

future_directions.name: Integration of Real-time Interrupt Mechanisms
future_directions.description: Explore the integration of real-time interrupt mechanisms for human scientists to monitor and intervene in the experiment’s progress.
future_directions.evidence: Addressing this limitation is a priority for future development, and we plan to explore the integration of real-time interrupt mechanisms.

future_directions.name: Optimization of Cost and Efficiency
future_directions.description: Further optimization to reduce costs and improve time efficiency of the k-agents system.
future_directions.evidence: We believe that there is potential for further optimization to reduce these costs.

resource_link.evidence: The source codes of k-agents can be found in [78].
